body: Do we plan to open some kind of RFC for the versioning? Right now it seems that there are many versions already (TVM release#, tophub distribution#, and now template#).

Remaining issue (possibly better left for a follow-up): keeping track of type environment in type infer (this is important for correctly handling let nodes: we have to generalize those functions immediately or else a case like the one I added in `test_proper_inner_function_generalization()` can't work). 

Currently, this would overgeneralize the type: the generalizer does not keep track of what type vars have been bound in an outer scope, so the inner function would be generalized over _all_ type vars that appear in it, including those that should be considered bound. I will have to think about how to adequately keep track of that, but suggestions would also be appreciated.
Ref. https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/running-error-in-from-tensorflow-py/1298

The general goal is to be able to cover all the cases in the scaffolding, and optionally extend them. The current proposal does not exclude mix signed/unsigned input though. The simple pattern matching could be done as (i8 cast to i16) mul (u8 -> cast to i16, which still can be lowered to normal ops

Hopefully before the end of this week, I'll complete writing the docs and be ready for PR. In the meantime, you can checkout the [resnet example](https://github.com/ehsanmok/tvm-rust/tree/master/examples/resnet).

@nhynes I'd like to know in the proposed setup 
```
tvm/rust/
    Cargo.toml  # a virtual manifest
    frontend/ 
        Cargo.toml
        src/
    runtime/  # what's currently in /tvm/rust/
         Cargo.toml
        src/
    tvm-sys  # <-- Raw extern C API generated from bindgen
        Cargo.toml
        src/
```
shall we have a common, unified `tvm-sys` (matching the released version) with bindgen so that both runtime and frontend can import?

Also for the `.rustfmt.toml` I'd highly suggest to use the official and very common `tab_spaces = 4` instead of `tab_spaces = 2` for the whole rust repo.

@tqchen Btw I don't want to go through impl of RPC as I haven't found a good Rust option satisfying the requirements yet. It needs separate work after the frontend is merged as well as contrib graph runtime support.
Thanks, @liangfu , this is merged.
@tqchen  & @yzhliu  welcome to review .
@tqchen Done.
@tqchen Any suggestions that where I should look at? Or it is OK?
@tqchen I addressed feedback.

>  common, unified tvm-sys

Unfortunately, no because bindgen doesn't work when the target is exotic (e.g., wasm or sgx). That's why the headers are checked in as code. You're welcome to keep it as a top-level crate, though

Let's see how else your implementation looks, though. We might want a top-level `common/` crate for shared functionality.

> `tab_spaces = 4`

Two spaces is also common. At Google, 2 is used to make deeply nested code more readable. I'll defer to other community members here, but my strong preference is two spaces since it makes code more readable (esp. for rust where functional patterns encourage deep nesting). Again, let's see how your PR looks before we make a final decision. We should update (and stabilize on) rustfmt 1.0 at the same time, too.
@ashutoshparkhi  suggest to raise another PR for dlpack changes.

There is a trade-off between a very detailed error messaging system vs the ease of programming. I agree that we should build a reasonable hierarchy in the python side of the error message. But sometimes adding one error type per function can be overkill

In the C++ side, one of the easy ways to solve this problem is to have a specific error message encoding convention by string and allows re-dispatch. Either way, it is good to have a concrete proposal on the proposed error hierarchy and we should do it incrementally.
How about we define the scope of an expression to be the least common ancestor of all the scopes that directly refers the expression?

- Is this additional level of redirection necessary in the tvm_trace_runtime? Currently, the feature being implemented seems to be fine to just call call_packed.
- One of the properties of trace is that we might want to return the same specific value x[i] when we trace the content, which might need some additional work in the compiler when seeing trace, this property seems not being reflected here.

@kevinthesun Can you be more specific that I can replicate it?

@ajtulloch @tqchen 
> Hi all. This is a very interesting problem. 
> I use the bug fixed version of tvm, and I edited this case a little, add cache_read/cache_write in schedule part.

```python
from topi.util import get_const_tuple
import tvm

def func(Elements, Lengths):
    def f(n, d):
        rg = tvm.reduce_axis((0, Lengths[n]))
        return tvm.sum(Elements[rg, d], axis=rg)

    (N,) = get_const_tuple(Lengths.shape)
    (_, D) = get_const_tuple(Elements.shape)
    return tvm.compute((N, D), f, name="Y")

def run(N, I, D):
    Elements = tvm.placeholder(shape=(I, D), dtype="float32", name="Elements")
    Lengths = tvm.placeholder(shape=(N,), dtype="int32", name="Lengths")
    Y = func(Elements, Lengths)
    s = tvm.create_schedule([Y.op])
    Elements_local = s.cache_read(Elements, "local", [Y])
    Lengths_local = s.cache_read(Lengths, "local", [Y])
    Y_local = s.cache_write(Y, "local")
    print(tvm.lower(s, [Elements, Lengths, Y], simple_mode=True))
    #print(tvm.save_json(Y))
    #f = tvm.build(s, [Elements, Lengths, Y], target="llvm")

run(N=10, I=10, D=128)
```

> Unfortunately, tvm.lower() fails with

```
tvm._ffi.base.TVMError: [08:42:49] /home/dylan/tvm/src/schedule/schedule_dataflow_rewrite.cc:166: Check failed: iv->iter_type == kDataPar (2 vs. 0) Can only relayout with in data parallel dimensions
```

> I don't known what is the main of the problem cause. I guess the problem is cause by the 

```
rg = tvm.reduce_axis((0, Lengths[n]))
```

@tqchen thanks for review.

> Is this additional level of redirection necessary in the tvm_trace_runtime? Currently, the feature being implemented seems to be fine to just call call_packed.

As far as I understood, to be able to handle packed function, and take action only on those functions which are registered in global registry, we need an additional runtime machinery, in my case I've added global function "tvm.trace_runtime" which checks the global registry for the registered trace callbacks and calls it if necessary. In other case if we use call_packed inside computation node and the packed function is not registered we will get an error.
So, if we use only call_packed without wrapping, we should explicitly pass the name of runtime handler as first arg
`call_packed ("tvm.trace_runtime", "tvm_global_callback", expr)`
instead
`tvm.trace("tvm_global_callback", expr)`
Can you please clarify, what do you think, should I delete those wrapping ?

> One of the properties of trace is that we might want to return the same specific value x[i] when we trace the content, which might need some additional work in the compiler when seeing trace, this property seems not being reflected here.

Thanks for mention this, I completely forget about return value. Before updating the patch, I want make sure, that I get your right about "work in the compiler".
Seems to me, I just can add return value to TVMRetValue
`*ret = args[1];`
and this requires some cosmetic changes in code which lowers tvm_call_packed
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/pass/lower_tvm_builtin.cc#L254
From:
```
return Call::make(
        Int(32), intrinsic::tvm_call_packed_lowered,
        packed_args, Call::Intrinsic);
```
To:
```
return Call::make(
        op->type, intrinsic::tvm_call_packed_lowered,
        packed_args, Call::Intrinsic);

```
and to the call_packed python wrapper to create a Call node with the actual type of processed Expr.
Can you please confirm it, or there are could be some problems which I don't see, because a lot of logic depends on packed functions.
cc @grwlf 
Thanks.

Thanks to everyone's effort, most of the ops are now supported. Let us open new threads to catch the remaining outliers when necessary
@yzhliu as of now, relay's set of optimization passes is on par with all the previous nnvm benchmarks we ran in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/apps/benchmark

What do we do about nnvm symbols that are called from topi? (NCHWc conv, Winograd, etc)

Or more generally, how should we update the existing alter_layout registrations in topi that assume NNVM v1 ? I assume alter_layout mechanics of NNVM v1 and Relay are not compatible, so there will be two registrations, one for v1 and another for Relay?

+1 to assigning graph partitions to threads instead of axes. There are some [convincing benchmarks and discussions](https://github.com/pytorch/glow/issues/1749) which suggest that cache locality is a primary performance booster.
@merrymercy is working on alt_layout and i think he already have a solution
Probably we have to introduce something like `F`, which can be either `nnvm.sym` or `relay.op.`

(A change I still want to work on that I think might fix the over-generalization issue is keeping track of a type environment in the type inference visitor instead of in the unifier, which I think should not have any state of its own beyond the solver's state. This would also allow us not to have to unnecessarily expose a unifier node. I have had trouble working out how it should work exactly, however.)

Slightly off the topic, I would say it could be better if we explicitly claim which syntactic sugar of Python is supported, and which is not. You might be interested in writing it in accordance with Python's official AST document, [Green Tree Snake](https://greentreesnakes.readthedocs.io/en/latest/). @were @kevinthesun

Personally I prefer the second method, to keep this under hybrid script. @junrushao1994 It's helpful to have such a doc for developer to check whether their code syntax is supported. We can start with adding something we don't think will support in the long term, such as break/continue.
@were yes, looks cool, can we do this for each pass?

@kevinthesun complicated jumps like break/continue is not possible in Halide, because it break all analysis conducted. Hence, it is not quite meaningful to add it to the hybrid script. Do you have specific use cases for break/continue?
@junrushao1994 I don't think we need to support those.

@xqdan I do not want to aggressively modify the codegen backend.
I believe dumping each pass requires this.
I just want to dump the normalized schedule, the highest level (maybe with canonical simplification).
Also, which one do you prefer?
@kevinthesun @xqdan @junrushao1994 Can you guys review it?
@grwlf NDArray has shape information from which the frontends can compute datasize. I used same for golang frontends. Not sure if we need this new API.

Thanks for raising this issue, it would be nice if we can move the discussion to https://discuss.tvm.ai/. For this particular problem, this is indeed a restriction of the DSL itself. Because cache read/write only allow relayout on spatial dimensions. You can however, do cache read/write then do manipulation on reduction domain

Normally if workload is big enough, our past experience in MXNet suggest that parallelization within op has better potential than bind parts to threads. The pipeline partition would be useful though on small ops

In inference, graph-level parallelism does not help that much (at least on CPU/GPU), because normally an operator has been big enough to occupy all CPU threads or GPU streaming processors. About small workloads, @tqchen @nhynes do you have any specific example of such workloads, i.e. that could be accelerated by multiple issuing, but couldn't be fused into a single kernel?

Glow is a framework that does not support multi-threading (at least at the time of writing this post), i.e. all their operators are single-threaded. This could somehow explain why multiple issuing helps in Glow (imho).
I don't have enough bandwidth recently

Actually, I have some doubts whether GetDataSize is placed correctly or not. Currently it operates on C structures from dlpack.h but is defined in C++ ndarray.h. By this PR I write its C version because I can't use C++ in my project. But probably we better should move its inline version to dlpack.h, where DLTensor is defined, and make it a reference implementation. No need in special C API function in this case. Please share your opinion.

> Glow [...] does not support multi-threading

Right, but that's what they're planning on doing now. They're going the graph partitioning route and have expressed that cache locality makes this approach more efficient than op-parallelism.

I can't quite think of an example of a "small" op in the world of fusion, though.

> Right, but that's what they're planning on doing now. They're going the graph partitioning route and have expressed that cache locality makes this approach more efficient than op-parallelism.

Looks very interesting. @were do you have some bandwidth looking into this?

I can see pro/cons of introducing this API. Given that this implementation is short and we could just use per front-end implementation of this feature. As a general principle, we want to keep C API stable. We can, however, benefit from more detailed comments in the dlpack structure to elaborate on how size can be calculated.

> I can see pro/cons of introducing this API. Given that this implementation is short and we could just use per front-end implementation of this feature. As a general principle, we want to keep C API stable. We can, however, benefit from more detailed comments in the dlpack structure to elaborate on how size can be calculated.

Thanks, please consider reviewing PR linked above.

@tmoreau89 As we are making progress to enable VTA for Intel FPGA, I found it is difficult to debug the generated hardware of the `compute` component, and there are several features not yet supported in the Intel HLS. Therefore, I'm wondering whether there is any plan to decompose the `compute` component into several smaller components. At least, it could be reasonably constructed with decoders, ALUs and GEMM modules.
@were I see. 2nd is better for me.

@kevinthesun totally agree with @were and @junrushao1994, to support continue and break, the whole TVM stack would need lots of stuff in traditional compilers, which will make things complicated. if any operators don't fit into abstraction of TVM, maybe it's better to support it with low level languages, such as CUDA c. Also it's interesting to see what's the real requirements look like.

@liangfu what are the features that aren't supported in Intel HLS that are making the process challenging? We could consider breaking modules into smaller components to make testing and debugging more easy. What did you have in mind?

> * The intrinsic attribute map and op map are mostly the same and maybe we want to share some data structure

which place is better, I'm considering in runtime/ just like registry of packed function

> * It is not too scalable to put everything as the member of the attribute, instead, maybe we can consider using additional attributes set_attr by default.
> * We do not need string(target) to function map, we can directly encode target name in the intrinsic name(e.g. tvm.intrin.cce.copy)

do you mean attr map is enough, just remove container of target hooks in Intrin class?

> * We don;t need to use any, instead use the same PackedFunc and TVMRetValue will automatically enable registrations in python side.

ok, if we can reuse the code from relay/op.h op.cc, this will be not an issue
I should mention that the vector add example in this PR use low level tvm API directly. There is no detail of topi, nnvm, or relay, to keep it simple.
How would this decision impact the development of MXNet? NNVM request will still be supported?

Running on inception-v3 produces segmentation fault. It seems some memory issue (some free'd memory accessed by `PyObject_Free`), I'm not sure about the exact cause. Could you take a look? @ZihengJiang @tqchen 
```
sym, params = tvm.relay.testing.inception_v3.get_workload(1)
sym = relay.quantize.quantize(sym, params)
graph, lib, params = relay.build(sym, target, params=params)
```

Thanks @JennyChou5 for the proposal. I think it is a good step of moving TVM to the product line.

What we should do is to define unified error types and encourage contributors to refer to as needed. We also should reasonably categorize the error types so that most of the functions can throw error in known types.

In terms of the layers proposed above (model parsing layer, NNVM/Relay pass layer, TVM compute layer, TVM schedule layer), I think we should add TVM runtime layer. Also, I am not sure if TVM compute and schedule should be divided, perhaps combining them and adding codegen layer instead?
Thanks @tqchen @yidawang  for the feedback. Will come out with proposed error hierarchy for review in each layer.

@tqchen I just look into the code in relay/op.h, trying to figure out how to reuse OpMap and GenericMap , but class objects in this file are mixing together, Op and GenericMap need Op and OpNode class when implementing get and [], do you have any suggestion?
